subject: Re: [junit] validate() and reset()
msgSnippet: These look like inherited methods on a Struts form object.  Assuming that you are going to override them to do something more than you have shown here, here
messageBody:
These look like inherited methods on a Struts form object. Assuming
that you are going to override them to do something more than you have
shown here, here are some things to think about testing in a unit
test.

reset(...) method test

- change a bunch of the fields on the form

- call reset() with a stub mapping & request

- make sure that the fields are set back to their default values
(writing the test is a good way to define/clarify what those
default values should be)


validate(...) method test

- One test where the form fields all contain valid values. Call
validate() and make sure that you get back either null or an empty
ActionErrors

- One test per validation rule that you implement. For each test,

* set up the invalid condition by setting the fields on the Form
* call validate(...) with a stub mapping & request
* ensure that the ActionErrors object contains the appropriate
error(s)

- A utility method is generally useful for examining the contents of
the ActionErrors object. You want to be able to write assertions
such as:

. verifyOneError("validation.date.format.prompts", "-1/1/2005");

. verifyTwoErrors("validation.date.format.prompts", "notADate",
. "validation.date.format.prompts", "badDate");



----- Original Message -----
From: "computing_skills" <Manoj.Lukhman@...>

> I have a two methods (see below) and would like to get some guidance
> on how to test for them.
>
> public void reset(ActionMapping mapping, HttpServletRequest
> request)
> {
> super.reset(mapping, request);
> }
>
> public ActionErrors validate(ActionMapping mapping,
> HttpServletRequest request)
> {
> return super.validate(mapping, request);
> }
>
